For startups with limited capital, cost-cutting is a fact of life. Luckily, outsourcing is one of the best ways to staff your company without breaking the bank… and it can help you save in more ways than one! Here’s how: 1. You can hire more employees for the same amount of capital. According to The International Labour Organization (ILO), the average monthly wage of most 1st world countries is approximately 3800 AUD. Compare this to salaries in countries such as the Philippines, which averages to a little under 380 AUD per month. Even with a quick glance at those figures, it’s easy to pick the more practical choice. Some may think that outsourcing means settling for low-quality work, but that’s not the case at all. In fact, workers in countries where outsourcing is an industry in and of itself are often college-educated and highly trained in their fields of expertise. Additionally, workers in countries such as India and the Philippines are fluent English speakers, making communication a non-issue. Of course, the best way to keep things running smoothly is to regularly communicate your needs with your outsourcing company. 2. You can spend less per employee. Hiring in-house is always the ideal scenario, but you have to factor in the combined cost of salaries and other full-time benefits. It doesn’t stop there: you have to provide equipment, software, and other necessities for each employee you hire just so they can get the job done… not to mention have enough space in your office to give them their own workstation. We haven’t even included the cost of recruiting each person. In fact, Forbes notes that hiring a new employee costs 1.25 to 1.4 times of said employee’s base salary range. That’s a lot of spending you might not be able to afford right off the bat, and where outsourcing makes the most sense. You’ll expect to spend around half of what you currently spend on in-house employees in terms of taxes, benefits, onboarding, and training… maybe even less. Plus, you can choose to bring them in only during peak seasons, further maximizing your spending.  3. You can run a more flexible team. It takes a lot of time and money to hire the perfect in-house employee. Thus, it’s in your best interests to keep your staff happy. However, losing employees is an almost inevitable part of owning a business. According to a paper published by the Center for American Progress, the average cost of employee turnover is over 200 percent of said worker’s compensation for a year, including the costs of recruiting, training, and onboarding, to name a few. However, you can sidestep all of that by staffing part of your team with offshore workers. Not only can you pretty much skip the hiring process, but you won’t have to spend as much time getting these workers up to speed, either. Since they’re already trained in their specific niches, all you have to do is reach out and bring them in whenever you need to. The same is true for letting go of offshore employees who don’t work out… and they’re infinitely easier to replace than in-house staff, that’s for sure. 4. You’ll be able to focus on more important things. In most startups, employees have to don many hats to get things done. Unfortunately, this can lead to employee burnout. Not only that, but it can greatly compromise the quality of your work. According to a study conducted by the University of London, the IQ of people who multitasked while carrying out cognitive tasks dropped significantly. An article on Inc. also notes that multitasking also pumps up the stress hormones in your body, making you feel more exhausted. Multi-tasking won’t just affect your physical and mental health, but your company’s bottom line, too. Studies conducted by Humboldt University show that distracted people take around 23 minutes to re-focus on important work, with interruptions causing employees to take approximately 50 percent longer to finish tasks. To make matters worse, said tasks will be completed with 50 percent more errors. If you multiply that by the number of people on your team, that’s a lot of hours going down the drain. By outsourcing menial work, you and your core team can place your full attention on higher-level tasks instead.  5. You can potentially keep your business running 24/7. There’s that age-old saying: “time is money.” And while running a business from 9 to 5 is still the norm, more and more consumers are expecting companies to be available for inquiries at odd hours. Thankfully, you can outsource services such as Customer Service and I.T. so that your clients and customers have someone to reach out to at any time of the day. Additionally, globalization has totally changed the game. Depending on what industry you work in, you don’t necessarily have to limit yourself to doing business only in the country where you’re based. Marketed properly, your company could earn from clients in other countries. The only problem is that your team is most likely asleep when your potential clients are up and about. But why close up shop when you can keep operations running? By hiring offshore workers, you can essentially keep your company open indefinitely, which means you won’t have to miss out on extra income. As an added bonus, these employees can also be pick up extra projects that your core team may not be able to get to. You may never have to say ‘we’re fully booked to another client ever again. (Of course, do all this within reason—outsourced employees are human and are prone to burnout, too.) If your business is struggling to stretch out that capital, outsourcing may be the answer you’ve been looking for. Hey Jake! It very much depends on their business, and type of process they choose to outsource. Start-ups for example. They often chose to outsource due to flexibility, short contracts, lack of in house knowledge and to make sure they can focus on making their business work. Outsourcing their Customer support or back office means they know this will be well taken care off, the provider will be guaranteeing the SLAs and KPIs so the owner can focus on their core business. It’s also common that as they grow, they wish to be able to offer 24/7 contact centers, and that is a lot easier to offer throgh outsourcing. In some cases we are even part of our clients business even before they launch. Having an outsourcing partner to the help build and plan their contact center solutions means they don’t need to focus on this at all, knowing they have experts helping them set it all up, and then running it. A lot of SMEs chose to start using outsourcing as they grow to be able to scale up in a fast but secure way, not having to hire a lot of staff locally while keeping the costs at a minimum. In these cases the company usually have a in house team already performing the tasks they wish to outsource. But by extending their operations with a remote team, they don’t need to worry about getting bigger offices, recruiting/hiring and managing a lot more staff, risking that non-core tasks start taking up to much or their focus. Often do they promote the local team to managers to manage the outsourced team and making sure that the quality of their services do not suffer. Basically how you would normally do on a local level, just at a much lower monthly costs and with no need of any investments in infrastructure.

Outsourcing offers a variety of advantages for companies of any kind, especially startups. After working for more than 10 years with software outsourcing, I see that startups are the main beneficiaries of outsourcing because it offers a collection of characteristics that are good for everyone, but great if you are an entrepreneur. By combining lower costs with high quality, some outsourcing providers out there can complement entrepreneurs who have good ideas, but are lacking technical knowledge or capacity. In addition, outsourcing companies often have a lean approach that is very positive for building MVPs. The use of Agile methodologies that encourage frequent releases and iterative models in which business ideas can be validated soon and cheap has allowed outsourcing providers to help entrepreneurs in building products who bring real value to its users. That’s for me the biggest outcome you can get from outsourcing and in this Medium post I share my perspectives of this advantage for startups of an specific industry, as an example.

Because division of labour is often efficient both from cost and quality point of view. With the advancement of both management and production technology it’s getting more and more difficult for in-house divisions to compete with commercial service. Take translation business - the activity that has long been outsourced by even those companies that translate humongous volumes of text on a constant basis. A specialised translation agency has tons of tricks to make their work more efficient - freelancers relations, computer-assisted translation tools, specialised management and organisational techniques, specialised project managers etc. etc. This takes years and millions of man-hours to build. And then it requires constant attention to maintain that edge and stay on top of the market - new stuff is being invented and introduced every day. As a result an in-house translation division will almost always be outperformed by a top-notch external agency. And what if your in-house service falls short? What if it’s mismanaged and inefficient? You, as a company, will have to own the losses. If an external supplier fails to deliver all you need to do is change the supplier and be top-notch again. This is why companies specialise - the way to survive on a highly competitive market is to be the very best at what you do. And that often means getting the very best suppliers too.
